title: Figma Brings Precision AI Image Editing Directly Into the Design Canvas

paragraphs.content: Figma has rolled out three new AI-powered tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—designed to bring precision image editing directly into Figma Design and Figma Draw.The update lets designers remove unwanted elements, isolate and adjust specific subjects, and extend image backgrounds to new aspect ratios without leaving the canvas.By building these capabilities into Figma’s core workflow, the company aims to reduce dependence on external editors like Photoshop for common production tweaks.Figma positions the release as a way to make “precision editing faster, cleaner, and more intuitive,” and to support a more complete creative workflow inside its platform.

paragraphs.content: The new tools live in a redesigned contextual image toolbar that also surfaces existing features such as Crop, Remove background, and AI image generation.Figma’s launch video highlights that users can now “make, edit, and refine visuals without ever leaving your file,” underscoring a push to keep all visual adjustments in one place.Industry coverage describes the suite as AI-assisted but deliberately *promptless*, favoring direct selection and manipulation over text-based commands.Commentators at AI-focused outlets say this approach is intended to streamline real-world design workflows rather than showcase experimental generative tricks.

sections.title: How Erase, Isolate, and Expand Change Everyday Design Workflows

paragraphs.content: The three tools target some of the most common pain points in digital design, starting with **Erase object**, which lets users select and remove distracting elements while automatically filling in the background.**Isolate object** allows designers to cut out a subject—such as a product or person—and then move it, or adjust lighting, blur, and color, without altering the rest of the scene.**Expand image** tackles the recurring challenge of adapting assets to multiple formats by extending an image’s background to fit new aspect ratios, like converting a square product shot into a wide hero banner.A short-form creator demoing the features described them as a way to stop “juggling between all the different design tools” for simple but time-consuming edits.

paragraphs.content: Figma has centralized these capabilities in a new contextual image toolbar that appears directly on the canvas when an image is selected, grouping AI tools alongside familiar actions like Crop and Remove background.The company notes that Remove background is one of the most frequently used actions on the platform, and it has been given more prominent placement in the updated interface.Release notes describe the toolbar as the home for all three AI tools—Expand image, Erase object, and Isolate object—so they are accessible in a single click during layout work.This consolidation is meant to reduce mode-switching and make precise visual refinements feel like a native part of wireframing, prototyping, and interface design rather than a separate specialist step.

sections.title: Strategic Stakes: Catching Up on AI While Doubling Down on In‑Canvas Editing

paragraphs.content: Industry analysts see the launch as Figma both closing a feature gap and sharpening its strategic positioning in the crowded AI design market.Rivals such as Adobe and Canva have offered object removal and AI-assisted image expansion for several years, and Figma is now “finally catching up” with its own integrated suite.At the same time, outlets like AI Insider emphasize that Figma’s implementation is tuned for UI and product work—focused on in-canvas adjustments rather than full-scale photo retouching.By embedding AI tools that don’t rely on text prompts, Figma is betting that designers and marketers want granular, controllable edits inside their existing files more than they want entirely new images generated from scratch.

The features are currently available to users with Full seats on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans in Figma Design and Figma Draw, with the company planning to expand availability across more products on its platform.Coverage notes that this rollout coincides with a broader wave of AI integrations across creative software, including Adobe’s move to surface similar capabilities inside conversational tools.Commentators suggest that keeping image manipulation tightly integrated with design files could speed up review cycles for marketing and product teams, who often need quick variations for different channels and devices.Looking ahead, analysts expect Figma to continue layering AI-driven editing and generation features into its ecosystem, further blurring the line between interface design, content creation, and production-ready asset preparation.
